HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)*TRAVELLING CONCESSIONS FOR RELATIVES VISITING GRAVES IN FRANCE AND BELGIUM.\:ith reference to Cabinet 21 (20), Minute 5 (a), I circulate the following extract from the Prime Ministers reply to a deputation from the National Federation of Discharged and Demobilised Sailors and Soldiers on 6th February 1920: "V/ith regard to war graves, let me say One word about that. I thoroughly agree that every facility ought to be given to the relatives of deceased soldiers to visit their children's graves but there are difficulties at the present moment. The devastated areas are really devastated and it is with the greatest difficulty that you can get there at all. The French are for the moment utilising the whole of the transport for the purpose of restoration, and it is very difficult to get there* As soon as it is practicable to do so, we will take this into account and we will try and arrange that facilities shall be organised for that purpose. The Government are entirely in sympathy with the object which you have in view there, but for the moment I am told that it is almost impracticable to arrange it,.owing to the reasons which I have already givesu"CABINET,RET1105 aNote by the Acting Secretary.Acting Secretary,2 "liitehall Gardens.
